curve as a way of describing how performance

313.text:
which I think is important to highlight here,

320.text:
The more experience you accumulate in a marketer
industry, the longer and harder you have to

326.text:
work to get the next increment of performance
improvement. It may help to explain why many

332.text:
of us are feeling increasing stress in the

339.text:
But what if there were an alternative? What
if we could turn the experience curve on its

345.text:
side and generate increasing returns, rather

355.text:
improvement accelerated as the number of participants
expands? Now that would be powerful, but what

364.text:
would it require? Well, I suggest it requires
a lot of things, and it starts with a major

371.text:
shift in our beliefs and our practices. It
s a key dimension of what we ve described

378.text:
in The Power of Pull as the big shift, and
as a result, I think it requires a shift in

384.text:
design focus so let me amplify a bit on that,
and when I talk about shift in beliefs, I

391.text:
m talking about a shift in our view of where
and how economic value gets created. The shorthand

400.text:
way we have of capturing that is saying we
re moving from a world of stocks to a world

405.text:
of flows. And what do I mean by that? Well,
I m referring in this case not to stocks that

411.text:
are traded on the stock market, but knowledge
stocks, what we know at any point in time,

417.text:
and it turns out if you ask any executive
and really probe as to their basic beliefs

421.text:
of what s created economic value, the basic
assumption is, first of all, you have to acquire

427.text:
some proprietary knowledge stocks, and then
you have to, aggressively as possible, protect

433.text:
those knowledge stocks from anybody else getting
access to them, and then as efficiently as

438.text:
possible, extract the value from those knowledge
stocks. Huge corporations were created in

445.text:
the 20th Century around this set of beliefs.
Enormous wealth generated around this set

450.text:
of beliefs. We make the case that, in fact,
we re shifting from a world of knowledge stocks

457.text:
to a world of knowledge flows, and the reason
for that is, if you think about it, anything

461.text:
you know today has more and more rapidly depreciating
value. What we know today has a very limited

471.text:
shelf life. The shelf life is shrinking over
time, and the only way you can create economic

477.text:
value in that kind of environment is to find
ways to more effectively participate in a

484.text:
larger number of more diverse knowledge flows
so that you can refresh those knowledge stocks

490.text:
at an accelerating rate. Fundamentally different
view of what s required to create economic

497.text:
value. Now in this context I m actually very
intrigued. I ve just recently encountered

503.text:
a set of design theories that are known as
constructal design theories generated by two

509.text:
people: Adrian Bejan and Sylvie Laurent, and
what they ve done is they ve built a design

516.text:
perspective based on what they call a constructal
law that they ve observed now in playing out

522.text:
across physical environments, biological environments
and social systems. And essentially what the

530.text:
constructal law says is that in order to survive,
systems have to evolve greater and greater

537.text:
access to the currents that flow through them.
Whether we re talking about riverbeds, trees,

548.text:
the design of our lungs or our cities, it
turns out they all obey this constructal law.

556.text:
Systems that survive and thrive are those
that evolve most rapidly and effectively to

563.text:
enhance those flows within those systems.
So I think two interesting implications from

570.text:
this perspective: one is that the whole emphasis
on system design is on enhancing flows. That

578.text:
really is the mark of a successful system
and experience within the system, and it s

583.text:
also an emphasis on evolving systems, not
static systems because the emphasis here is

588.text:
these systems are continually evolving, and
if they re not they re in trouble, and they

592.text:
re continuing evolving along a certain pattern,
which is how do you more effectively generate

597.text:
and support the flows within the system. So
what would it mean to design the systems we

605.text:
live and work in to continually evolve our
ability to experience more and more flow,

611.text:
especially the flow of people and of ideas?
So that s one shift: the shift in beliefs

623.text:
from stocks to flows. There s a corollary
to this, which is a shift in practices. If

630.text:
they were fundamentally changing in terms
of where the source of economic value is,

634.text:
it stands to reason that the practices we
use to create economic value are going to

639.text:
have to change in a significant way as well,
and the way we capture this is the notion

644.text:
of moving from a world of push to a world
of pull. Again, if you go back in time to

652.text:
the 20th Century, the large companies that
succeeded in the 20th Century were operating

658.text:
on a push model. Basically said the key is
to forecast and predict demand, and then make

665.text:
sure that all the right people and resources
are in the right place at the right time to

670.text:
meet that demand. Again, huge multinational
corporations created with this push model,

676.text:
enormous wealth created. On the other hand,
if we re living in a more uncertain and more

682.text:
rapidly changing world, that kind of push
model becomes more and more challenging, more

688.text:
and more problematic, and the questions is
then, well, what s the replacement? What s

693.text:
the option? Well, we argue that it s all about
pull practices. Now many of you, when I say

699.text:
pull, are going to have a certain mindset
or image of what I mean by pull. I want to

704.text:
kind of expand that, hopefully. I think it
probably expands by talking about three levels

709.text:
of pull that are becoming increasingly important.
There s one level, which is probably the most

715.text:
obvious, which I call access. It s simply
the notion of how do I more effectively access

722.text:
people and resources when I need them or where
I need them? It s basic search functionality

727.text:
that Google offers. It s the shift from push-based
media to pull-based media so you can pull

733.text:
the media you want, experience at any point
in time wherever you want it. Now that s a

739.text:
powerful of pull, but it s just the first
level. I haven t even begun to tap into the

745.text:
opportunity around pull, which comes starting
with the second level, which is the notion

750.text:
of attraction. Here s the challenge: In a
world that s more rapidly changing, you don

756.text:
t even know what to look for, what questions
to ask, what to search for. The only way you

764.text:
re going to survive and thrive in that kind

770.text:
to you that you never even knew existed, and

776.text:
an unexpected encounter. You run into somebody.
You start up a conversation. Start talking

782.text:
about some of the issues you re dealing with,

785.text:
d been struggling with for months. Enormously

794.text:
serendipity, most people respond, Yeah, but

can do about serendipity. It just happens.
All you can do is be prepared for it when

812.text:
You can increase both the probability and
the quality of those unexpected encounters

819.text:
by making choices about where you spend your
time and how you spend your time. Significant

826.text:
potential to affect that serendipity, that
ability to pull that second level of pull,

835.text:
but there s a third level that s even more
interesting, and this is the one I focus on

839.text:
in the context of this discussion around design

845.text:
of pull is what I call achieve. It s the notion

851.text:
institutions we work in the full potential

859.text:
It gets to the notion of learning, more rapid
learning, more rapid performance improvement

865.text:
by using those first two levels of pull and

871.text:
s where the real power of pull comes in, is

878.text:
pressure, that s the opportunity to shift

884.text:
But the key question is how do you design

893.text:
those scalable pull experiences? It s not
just with a few friends or coworkers, but

901.text:
to really be successful we talk about the

in a global basis where you can draw out people

916.text:
but around the world, wherever they reside?
Now I confess I don t have the answers to

925.text:
these questions that I m posing. I don t think

930.text:
I think they re such interesting questions,
but I m hoping to intrigue and tease enough

935.text:
of you that you ll start to come up with the

In fact, one without the other becomes not

pull platforms, to that big opportunity that

12 million participants are organized into

not just within the team, but across teams,

teams to make them even more successful. There

amount of time with and we talk about in the

their physical environment, but the scalability

and the social relationships that have emerged

1230.text:
those are a couple of interesting examples

1236.text:
that create scalable pull in the sense of

1241.text:
more rapid performance improvement as more

1248.text:
in a business context. I mentioned there was
a second design challenge, though, which is

1255.text:
not just the platforms. It has to do with

1260.text:
these kinds of scalable pull platforms in
front of an executive is going to get a bleary

1264.text:
look on the face and say, Well, wait a minute.
I m over here. You re talking about something

1270.text:
that s way out there. How they hell am I going

1275.text:
pathway that helps people to move in a pragmatic
way from where they are today to where they

1281.text:
need to be, it s going to be a very short
conversation. So in that context I want to

1289.text:
tell a bit of a story around a company that

1294.text:
pull. It s a company I think most of you are
probably familiar with. It s in the software

1301.text:
business and it s called SAP. SAP was at one
time a highly entrepreneurial company. The

1309.text:
founder of it, Hasso Plattner, amazing guy,

1316.text:
the software technology and work that he did.
He became more and more concerned as his company

1328.text:
kind of bureaucratic tradition-bound risk
averse, not invented here kinds of cultures

1336.text:
that many of us are familiar with in large

1344.text:
And what he did was he went out and he bought
a company, and he bought the company not particularly

1351.text:
because the company was great, but because
he wanted the guy who was the founder of that

1355.text:
company. It was a guy by the name of Shai
Agassi. Not many of you may be familiar with

1361.text:
Shai. He made Shai a very senior executive

in charge of the core part of my business
because if I do they re going to kill you

1372.text:
over there, and you re a really nice guy.
I don t want to see you killed. So what I

1379.text:
m going to do is I m going to put you in charge
of a part of the business that s on the edge.

1384.text:
It s a new product that we re introducing
called NetWeaver. It s generating a very limited

1389.text:
amount of revenue and no profit so nobody
is going to pay attention to it over in the

1396.text:
core of the business. You ll have degrees
of freedom out there that you wouldn t have

1400.text:
if you were in the core, and he said, I want

1405.text:
to redefine how we work together and how we

1412.text:
What Shai did was he created a platform called
the SAP Developer Network, and initially it

1422.text:
was a very simple platform. It basically was
an environment you could come into, an online

1426.text:
environment, where if you were a developer
working on this NetWeaver product and running

1432.text:
into programming issues, as many people would,

1439.text:
else had had an experience that was equivalent
could help you work your way through the problem

1444.text:
you were wrestling with. Really simple. Basically

1454.text:
And it turns out now SAP Developer Network
has about two million software developers

1461.text:
actively participating on this network, and
again, it s growing at a very rapid rate.

1467.text:
It s scaling. And it has generated enormous
productivity on the part of these software

1476.text:
developers, and the initial focus of the platform
was actually software developers outside of

1482.text:
SAP. It was software developers in third-party
channels, software developers in the customers,

1488.text:
not the SAP developers because the SAP developers
had this mindset that how can you possibly

1494.text:
learn from anybody outside our company. You
know, we re an incredibly successful company.

1499.text:
Well, it turns out over time more and more
of the SAP developers have migrated out into

1505.text:
this developer network because word has spread
that it s an amazing productivity tool. You

1511.text:
can develop more rapidly, learn more quickly
as part of this network than you ever could

1516.text:
working on your own or working as part of
your local team. So very interesting progression

1525.text:
over time. I tell the story because I think
it illustrates a number of elements of pathways

1532.text:
that are going to be important to realizing
this opportunity to create scalable pull platforms.

1540.text:
One of the pathways is the notion of starting
with a very simple transaction in these environments.

1548.text:
There s often a temptation to go out with
very elaborate kind of learning environments

1554.text:
and performance improvement environments.
This was a simple question and answer discussion

1560.text:
forum: Pose the problem. See if anybody else
has an answer to it, and then move to using

1568.text:
that to build reputation and relationships.
What happened was that as people started answering

1575.text:
the problems, they developed a reputation.
They actually got points. SAP awarded them

1582.text:
points for each successful answer that was
delivered, and they built a reputation around

1588.text:
those points. Interesting sidelight, it turns
out that a lot of software recruiters had

1594.text:
figured out that if you re looking for a software

go into the SAP Developer Network and look

1605.text:
people who are really successful at answering

1611.text:
out even though those people offering answers

1616.text:
for their answers, they were getting some

1621.text:
of having done that. More motivation to contribute
even more. And by the way, I should say at

1628.text:
this point the average time to answer a problem
that s provided on the SAP Developer Network

1634.text:
is about 17 minutes from the time it s posed
to the time the problem is resolved 17 minutes.

1642.text:
So it s a very, very successful platform in
that regard. But what s happened is then you

1647.text:
ve got a third level of progression and evolution,
which is the notion that over time, as a result

1654.text:
of this reputation and the relationships that
emerge, because people were seeking each other

1659.text:
out as they saw each other s reputation in

on more and more challenging application development

1671.text:
their current coding efforts, but actually
came together from around the world to develop

1678.text:
entirely new applications, again, based on
the reputation and relationships that they

1683.text:
had built as part of this environment. So
it s an interesting progression. It says start

1691.text:
with very simple kinds of transactions and
build on that over time so you get these relationships

1697.text:
emerging and more interesting learning environments
begin to surface over time. There s a second

1705.text:
dimension to the pathway, which is that the
model that Shai used here, as an entrepreneur

1711.text:
in the software industry, he was a big proponent

1718.text:
and so the notion of deploying this network
in very short increments, getting it out there,

1724.text:
watching how people behaved on these networks
and what kinds of things were working, what

1729.text:
wasn t, and then doing another iteration based
on that was a very powerful way to learn from

1737.text:
the participants and not simply spend a ton
of money upfront trying to figure out what

1742.text:
they would need. So that s a second dimension.
A third dimension is this notion of starting

1749.text:
on the edge. You know, there s a big question
of how do you get change to happen. If we

1756.text:
re talking about scalable pull platforms with
large enterprises, that s really hard to accomplish

1762.text:
given the deeply held beliefs and practices
that drive the core. Most of the cores of

1768.text:
our companies are push-based cores, and so
the notion of not trying to change the core,

1776.text:
but going out to an interesting edge and driving
change from the edge, and by the way, not

1782.text:
bringing that edge back into the core. So
they would have killed the developer network

1788.text:
if they tried to bring it back into the core.
What they were doing was creating more and

1793.text:
more incentive and motivation to pull more
and more of the people in the core and resources

1800.text:
in the core out to the edge and scale the
edge even more rapidly around a very different

1806.text:
set of practices than had prevailed within
SAP at the time. There s another dimension

1814.text:
of the pathway which I think becomes extremely
important to drive the movement, and that

1822.text:
s the notion of performance metrics to measure
progress, and I think what s particularly

1828.text:
interesting about this opportunity for more
rapid performance improvement is it almost

1832.text:

drone aircraft technology than anybody I ve

3664.text:
ever met, and he finally asked the question.
He said, Where did you get your PhD from?

3670.text:
And there was kind of this awkward silence
on the other end of the discussion forum.

3675.text:
The guy evaded the question, and they went
on in the conversation and the more they talked

3681.text:
the more excited Christ became, and he ultimately
got enough trust with the guy to probe and

3686.text:
find out who and where he was. It turns out
he was at the time a 19-year-old high-school

3694.text:
graduate in Tijuana, Mexico. Who would have
thought to look among high-school graduates

3704.text:
in Tijuana, Mexico to find the CTO of your
tech startup? This guy, now 23, is the CTO

3713.text:
of Chris startup; has moved to the United
States. But I think it s a great example of

3719.text:
serendipity in action. You often don t know
where to look for the people who are going

3722.text:
to be most valuable to you, and if you don
t participate in environments that help you

3727.text:
to have those unexpected encounters, you re
going to be increasingly challenged. Thank

3729.text:
you. [End of Audio] [Vimeo-210831897] Keynote_John
